text: There's a lot we don't know about the
digital warfare that's going on. Both
sides have developed military plans to
uh disable the u the internet or
digital resources of of a possible
adversary. And that's not a secret. It's
very difficult to
say who has the upper hand in this
battle because uh the United States is
certainly well aware of the
vulnerability of our infrastructure, our
power grid, our electric grid, our our
communications grid, our air aviation
uh grid. We're very vulnerable as a as a
highly industrialized society and and
China is becoming more and more of a
global economic power. So they in turn
are vulnerable. Right now the focus
seems to be on hacking by China into uh
Google for example and into I think 34
American companies um at the time that
Google threatened to pull out of China
and not very much on what the United
States may be doing. So we don't know we
don't know because that's that hasn't
been publicized in the way that China's
activities have been publicized. There
is this problem of
attribution because when something is
hacked whether it be an individual or
company uh and a Trojan horse is put in
or some kind of worm or virus um there's
all always the question of you know is
this being done by some high school
student in Shboan or uh is it being done
from Estonia
uh with someone pretending they're a
server in China or is it being done in
Taiwan or is it being done in China and
that problem of attribution makes it
very difficult to say yes the Chinese
are doing this the Chinese government is
doing this and it's policy of the uh
Beijing leaders we can't say that we
don't know that even though all the
signs point to
